Award.AwardTitle: The relative Fukaya category and mirror symmetry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of the project is to investigate holomorphic curve invariants of symplectic manifolds, in particular the Gromov-Witten invariants, symplectic cohomology, and the Fukaya category. These invariants are of central importance in symplectic topology, and also have wider applications to low-dimensional topology (via Heegaard-Floer-type invariants), algebraic geometry (via mirror symmetry), and string theory. Following the guiding philosophy of Kontsevich's homological mirror symmetry conjecture, certain relationships between these invariants are expected, and the main aim of the project is to establish these relationships, while staying firmly rooted in explicit examples and computations.

Broadly, the project investigates symplectic manifolds, which are spaces that locally look like the phase spaces of classical mechanics. Given a symplectic manifold, one can cook up a variety of interesting structures (called 'invariants'), bearing a strong resemblance to ideas coming from string theory; in fact, in some sense these invariants describe what physics would look like for strings living on a space with a symplectic structure. Investigations by physicists have predicted surprising connections between the physics experienced by particles living on spaces with a symplectic structure, and that experienced by particles living on a completely different kind of space: a space with an algebraic structure. This deep connection between two completely different kinds of spaces is very surprising, and not at all well-understood. Even so, it is very useful for mathematicians who study invariants of symplectic manifolds, because it gives predictions for what they should be in terms of algebraic geometry, which one can then set about verifying mathematically. The project aims to follow this strategy to investigate certain kinds of symplectic invariants, which have a variety of useful applications in different areas of mathematics and physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are two kinds of geometry that were central to this project: complex geometry, the study of manifolds equipped with a notion of multiplication by i (the square root of -1); and symplectic geometry, the study of manifolds equipped with a notion of two-dimensional area. Mirror symmetry is a conjectural deep relationship between these two very different fields, which has its origins in modern theoretical physics. It was originally phrased in enumerative terms: certain counts of objects on a symplectic manifold turned out to be equal to counts of analogous objects on a "mirror" complex manifold. However in 1994, Kontsevich conjectured that this enumerative version of mirror symmetry was a reflection of a much more profoud relationship, which is best phrased in more abstract terms: the 'Fukaya category' of a symplectic manifold is equivalent to the 'derived category' on the mirror complex manifold. This deeper and more abstract version is called 'homological mirror symmetry'. Unfortunately it remains firmly a conjecture: there are very few cases in which it is known to be true.

The aim of the project was twofold: to develop techniques for proving this conjecture, and apply them to prove it in some specific cases; and to explain the relationship between the homological and the enumerative versions of the conjecture. Both of these aims were achieved (although not all of the resulting papers are finished).

Firstly, in joint work with Sheel Ganatra and Tim Perutz, Sheridan was able to prove that (a certain version of) homological mirror symmetry implies enumerative mirror symmetry. Concretely, this allows one to count certain objects via an abstract approach using the Fukaya and derived categories. He also proved a series of results which reduce proving homological mirror symmetry to successively easier tasks: first, in joint work with Perutz, he proved that instead of matching up the entire Fukaya category with the entire derived category (these categories can be large and unruly), it suffices to match up certain more reasonable sub-categories, so long as they are 'large enough' in a precise sense; and second, he proved a 'versality' result which says that, in order to match up these sub-categories, it suffices to match up certain deformations of them. These deformations are much easier to compute explicitly than the originals. Thus the original problem of proving homological mirror symmetry is reduced to a feasible computation, which in certain cases can be carried out.

For example, in joint work with Ivan Smith, Sheridan was able to apply this series of results to prove that homological mirror symmetry holds in a large new class of cases: the so-called 'Greene-Plesser mirror pairs'. This has some interesting results: it allows them to answer natural questions about symmetries of symplectic manifolds by translating them to questions about symmetries of the Fukaya category, and thence into question about symmetries of the derived category of the mirror manifold (via the newly-proven cases of homological mirror symmetry), which can be solved using techniques of algebraic geometry (in particular, work of Tom Bridgeland). 

Sheridan gave a number of expository lecture courses about related subjects: a series of 12 lectures about homological mirror symmetry; a summer course for graduate students about the Fukaya category, which consisted of 4.5 hours of lectures and an extensive exercise sheet; and he designed a 15-lecture workshop for graduate students focusing on one specific case of homological mirror symmetry (for hypersurfaces in projective space). Links to the notes (and in some cases, videos) were posted on his website so they can reach a wider audience. He also helped a group of graduate students to run an informal learning seminar about holomorphic curve invariants (the Fukaya category is one such invariant). He co-organized a weekly seminar on symplectic geometry, joint between Princeton University and the Institute for Advanced Study, throughout the duration of the award.
